questions.text: During neonatal resuscitation at which heart rate you will start chest compression? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Heart rate less than 60

 

During neonatal resuscitation chest compression start at heart rate less than 60.

 

  • Heart rate less than 100/min - PPV with bag and mask on room air, SPO2 monitoring
  • Heart rate is below 60 - chest compressions (3:1)
  • Heart rate still remains less than 60 - IV epinephrine.

 

Educational Objective:


During neonatal resuscitation, chest compressions should be initiated if the heart rate falls below 60 beats per minute despite adequate positive pressure ventilation.

 

Neonatal Resuscitation algorithm-2015 update

questions.text: All of the following are components of Tetralogy of Fallot EXCEPT? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tricuspid stenosis

 

Tricuspid stenosis is not a component of Tetralogy of Fallot, where as the Pulmonary infundibular stenosis is included in Tetralogy of Fallot.

 

Tetralogy of Fallot (components of TOF)

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Large VSD
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Pulmonary stenosis
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Overriding of Aorta
  4. ﻿﻿﻿Right ventricular hypertrophy

 

It is the Most common congenital cyanotic heart disease seen in children

 

 

Cor en sabot or Boot shaped heart on chest X ray

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetralogy of Fallot consists of four components: a large ventricular septal defect (VSD), pulmonary stenosis, an overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text: A mother with her preterm newborn is worried as the newborn hasn't passed the meconium till now. What is the maximum time to wait for meconium to pass in this infant? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 48 hours

 

  • The normal newborn will pass urine within 24 hrs and Meconium within 48 hrs.
  • The time taken to reach air to the descending colon is 8-9 hrs.
  • Delayed passage of meconium is seen in case of Hirschsprung's disease

 

Meconium is often evacuated within 6 hours of birth or earlier, however it can be delayed up to 24-48 hours.

 

 

Pancreatic atresia or pancreatic duct stenosis may also cause meconium ileus.

 

Educational Objective:


A normal newborn should pass meconium within 48 hours after birth; delays beyond this may indicate Hirschsprung's disease or other gastrointestinal pathology.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is having multiple episodes of vomiting and is not able to drink orally. IV maintenance fluid needed to give in this child weighing 17 kg in 24 hours is: (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1350 ml

 

For this calculation daily maintenance fluid, the following table is considered.

 

 

For 1st 10 kg- 100ml/kg

 

For next 10kg-50ml/kg

 

Weight beyond 20kg-20ml/kg

 

For child weighting 17kgs: 10×100=1000ml

 

7×50=350ml

 

Total=1350ml

 

Educational Objective:


The daily IV fluid maintenance requirement in children weighing 10-20 kg is 100 mL/kg for the first 10 kg and 50 mL/kg for every kg between 10-20 kg.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents for an antenatal check-up and is currently on lithium for her bipolar disorder. This drug must be stopped, due to the risk of development of which of the following conditions in the fetus? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ebstein anomaly

 

Lithium should be stopped during pregnancy, as the prenatal consumption of lithium in pregnancy may lead to Ebstein abnormality.

 

Ebstein’s anomaly

 

 

The tricuspid valve is malformed such that it leaks, and is set further into the right ventricle than normal.

 

Clinical features

 

  • Cyanosed at birth
  • Loud murmur of tricuspid regurgitation
  • Can be very sick
  • May be associated with maternal lithium ingestion

 

ECG

 

  • Prolonged PR interval.
  • May have a superior axis

 

Chest X-ray

 

  • Massive cardiomegaly (wall-to-wall heart)
  • Reduced pulmonary vascular markings

 

Management

 

  • Resuscitate
  • Pulmonary vasodilator therapy (ventilation, oxygen)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. VACTERAL defects: VACTERAL is an acronym representing a group of birth defects that affect various parts of the body (vertebral defects, anal atresia, cardiac defects, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal anomalies, and limb abnormalities). These are not typically associated with lithium use during pregnancy.

 

Option C. Coarctation of aorta: Coarctation of the aorta is a narrowing of the aorta, often associated with Turner syndrome. It is not commonly linked to maternal lithium use.

 

Option D. Supravalvular aortic stenosis: Supravalvular aortic stenosis is a narrowing of the ascending aorta above the aortic valve and is associated with Williams syndrome. This condition is not related to lithium exposure during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prenatal exposure to lithium can lead to Ebstein's anomaly, characterized by the downward displacement of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle, resulting in significant cardiac defects and requiring prompt medical management at birth.

 

Ref - OP Ghai 9th Edition. Page No- 420-423.

questions.text: Which drug is preferred in premature neonates for closure of PDA? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ibuprofen

 

In premature newborns, Ibuprofen is currently preferred over Indomethacin as the medication of choice for the closure of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).

 

  • Ibuprofen: It is effective in promoting the closure of PDA in premature neonates. It inhibits the production of prostaglandins, which are responsible for keeping the ductus arteriosus open.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Indomethacin: Indomethacin is also used to close PDA and works similarly by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis. However, Ibuprofen is generally preferred due to a potentially better safety profile and similar efficacy.

 

Option C. Mefenamic acid: Mefenamic acid is not typically used for PDA closure in neonates. It is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) but not indicated for this specific use.

 

Option D. Paracetamol (Acetaminophen): Paracetamol can also be used for PDA closure in some cases, particularly when NSAIDs are contraindicated. However, it is not the first-line treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ibuprofen is the preferred drug for the closure of PDA in premature neonates due to its effectiveness and safety profile. Recognizing the appropriate pharmacological treatment for PDA is crucial in neonatal care.

questions.text: Which neonatal condition is the gastric aspirate shake test used to evaluate? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Respiratory distress syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

The gastric aspirate shake test is a simple bedside test used to assess pulmonary surfactant in newborns. It evaluates the presence of surfactant in gastric aspirate, which correlates with surfactant levels in the lungs. This test is specifically used to evaluate for Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS), also known as Hyaline Membrane Disease, which is caused by surfactant deficiency in premature infants.

 

In this test, gastric fluid is aspirated from the newborn and mixed with ethanol and saline. The mixture is then shaken and observed for stable foam formation. The presence of stable foam indicates adequate surfactant (negative test), while absence of foam indicates surfactant deficiency (positive test), suggesting RDS.

 

The test is particularly valuable in resource-limited settings where more sophisticated tests like amniotic fluid lecithin/sphingomyelin ratio or lamellar body counts may not be available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tracheoesophageal fistula - Incorrect. Diagnosis of TEF usually involves passing a radiopaque nasogastric tube and obtaining radiographs to demonstrate coiling of the tube in the proximal esophageal pouch. The shake test has no role in diagnosing TEF.

 

Option C. Meconium aspiration syndrome - Incorrect. MAS is diagnosed based on history of meconium-stained amniotic fluid, clinical signs of respiratory distress, and characteristic radiographic findings. The shake test is not used in MAS evaluation.

 

Option D. Transient tachypnea of the newborn - Incorrect. TTN is diagnosed based on clinical presentation and radiographic findings showing fluid in the interlobar fissures and perihilar streaking. The shake test doesn't help in TTN diagnosis as surfactant levels are normal in TTN.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The gastric aspirate shake test is a simple bedside test to evaluate surfactant deficiency in neonates, helping to diagnose Respiratory Distress Syndrome, particularly in settings where sophisticated laboratory tests are unavailable.

questions.text: In fetal circulation, which vessel carries deoxygenated blood back to the placenta? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Umbilical artery

 

The umbilical arteries are responsible for transporting deoxygenated blood from the fetal heart to the placenta during gestation. In general, arteries carry oxygenated blood away from the heart, but the pulmonary and umbilical arteries are unique in that they carry deoxygenated blood.

 

 

Clinical significance:

 

  1. The medial umbilical ligament is the remnant of the umbilical artery. The umbilical artery has the following fate:
    • Proximal parts persist as the superior vesical arteries
    • Distal parts get obliterated and form the medial umbilical ligaments
  2. The normal umbilical cord contains 2 arteries and 1 vein. A single umbilical artery is the most common cord abnormality. The incidence is higher in twin deliveries. Thus, identifying this during the head-to-toe examination of the newborn becomes extremely important. Congenital anomalies are seen in 30% of cases with a single umbilical artery, trisomy 18 is a common association.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Umbilical Vein: The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus.

 

Option C. Descending Aorta: In fetal circulation, the descending aorta distributes oxygenated blood from the heart to the lower parts of the body and is not specifically involved in the transport of deoxygenated blood to the placenta.

 

Option D. Pulmonary Artery: The pulmonary artery carries deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle to the lungs in postnatal circulation but does not play a role in fetal circulation in terms of transport to the placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In fetal circulation, the umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta.

questions.text: A 8-day old neonate with respiratory distress showed the following findings on chest X-ray. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital Diaphragmatic hernia

 

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia is the diagnosis based on the clinical scenario and X-ray.

 

Bochdalek hernia is the most prevalent type of it.

 

It is caused by a deficiency in the pleuroperitoneal membrane in the Posterolateral aspect.

 

Morgagni hernia is caused by a deficiency in the anterior pleuroperitoneal membrane.

 

Pathophysiology and cause

 

  • Cause is unknown
  • Failure of normal closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal in the developing embryo Abdominal contents herniate and compress the ipsilateral developing lung, causing pulmonary hypoplasia and hypertension.

 

Types of congenital diaphragmatic hernia

 

Bochdalek hernia: Bochdalek hernia: Poster lateral (occurring at approximately 6 weeks' gestation) Morgagni hernia: Morgagni hernia: Anteromedial - The hiatus hernia

 

Protrusion of abdominal organs through opening in diaphragm.

 

Clinical Presentation:

 

  • Mild to severe respiratory distress
  • Tachypnea, cyanosis, dyspnea
  • Absent breath sound.
  • Shock.

 

Three general presentations:

 

Severe respiratory distress Severe respiratory distress at the time of birth. (Severe hypoplasia) Respiratory deterioration hours after delivery (honeymoon period).

 

Benefit from correction of hypoxemia and pulmonary hypertension.

 

Diagnosis - Therapeutic Symptoms Radiographic study.

 

Prenatally as early as 25 weeks of gestation.

 

Therapeutic

 

Supportive treatment of respiratory distress (Use of end tracheal intubation, oxygenation).

 

Prophylactic antibiotics.

 

Surgical reduction of hernia and repair of defect.

 

Surgical Care - Antenatal

 

Open Fetal Surgery:

 

  • Involves removing compression on the abdominal viscera in the fetus.
  • Considered high-risk for both the mother and the fetus.
  • Does not provide a survival advantage.

 

Fetal Tracheal Occlusion:

 

  • Involves stimulating lung growth in the fetus by accumulating fluid in the lungs.
  • Results in larger but persistent abnormal lungs.

 

Steroid Therapy:

 

  • Administering steroids weekly can help improve lung function in foetuses.
  • However, the use of steroids in this context is controversial.
  • This is because there is a risk of adverse effects on brain and body development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation (CCAM): Congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation (CCAM) is a developmental anomaly of the lung characterized by cystic lesions in the lung. However, this does not present with herniated abdominal organs on imaging.

 

Option C. Bronchogenic cysts: Bronchogenic cysts are benign cysts that develop from abnormal budding of the bronchial tree. These typically present as mediastinal masses on imaging, not as herniated abdominal organs.

 

Option D. Hyaline membrane disease: Hyaline membrane disease (also called respiratory distress syndrome) presents in preterm infants with diffuse lung disease due to surfactant deficiency. It does not show herniated organs or diaphragmatic defects on imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (CDH), particularly Bochdalek hernia, is a diaphragmatic defect that leads to herniation of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity, causing severe respiratory distress due to lung compression and pulmonary hypoplasia.

 

Ref - Nelson 21st Edition – Page No- 3855-3856

questions.text:
What are the components of Nada's Minor Criteria? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Systolic mumur Grade 3
  2. Diastolic murmur
  3. Abnormal second heart sound
  4. Abnormal BP
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 and 4

 

Nada’s criteria is used for detection of CHD on the basis of clinical evaluation.

 

 

Presence of 1 major or 2 minor criteria suggest presence of heart disease.

 

Educational Objective:
 

In Nada’s criteria for detecting congenital heart disease, minor criteria include an abnormal second heart sound and abnormal blood pressure. The presence of one major or two minor criteria suggests the presence of heart disease.

questions.text: Identify the condition in the image shown below? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cephal hematoma

 

A cephal hematoma is a collection of blood between the skull and the periosteum and is typically limited by the edges of the skull bones. It does not cross suture lines because the bleeding is confined by the bone edges. This differentiates it from other types of scalp swellings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Caput succedaneum: Caput succedaneum refers to diffuse swelling of the scalp that crosses the suture lines and extends beyond the presenting part of the baby's head. It is caused by pressure from the birth canal during delivery.

 

Option C. Subgaleal hematoma: A subgaleal hematoma is a collection of blood between the scalp galea aponeurosis and the periosteum of the skull. It typically presents as a diffuse, boggy swelling that can cross suture lines and extend over large areas of the scalp.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect as the image and description fit the characteristics of a cephal hematoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A cephal hematoma is a collection of blood between the skull and the periosteum, confined by the bone edges, and does not cross suture lines.

questions.text: During neonatal resuscitation of a term baby, what is the amount of oxygen you will start with? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 21%


During neonatal resuscitation, the initial amount of oxygen administered to a term baby is 21%, which corresponds to the concentration of oxygen in room air. The rationale behind starting with 21% oxygen is to avoid the potential risks associated with high concentrations of oxygen, such as oxidative stress and damage to the delicate tissues of a newborn, particularly the lungs and eyes.

 

Bag and mask ventilation using an AMBU (Artificial Manual Breathing Unit) bag, also known as a self-inflating bag, is the standard method used during neonatal resuscitation. The oxygen concentration delivered can vary depending on the setup:

 

  • AMBU without reservoir and without oxygen inlet: Provides 21% oxygen, as it uses room air.
  • AMBU with a reservoir and with oxygen inlet: Can deliver close to 100% oxygen.
  • AMBU with a reservoir but without an oxygen inlet: Delivers approximately 40% oxygen.

 

Given the guidelines and the need to balance adequate oxygenation with minimizing the risks of hyperoxia, resuscitation of a term newborn typically begins with 21% oxygen, with adjustments made based on the infant’s response and ongoing clinical assessment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 50%: Starting with 50% oxygen is not standard practice for neonatal resuscitation, as the recommendation is to start with room air (21%) and adjust as necessary.

 

Option C. 100%: High concentrations of oxygen, such as 100%, are avoided initially due to the risks of oxygen toxicity and oxidative stress, which can cause harm to the newborn, particularly to the eyes (risk of retinopathy of prematurity) and lungs.

 

Option D. 75%: Similar to 50% and 100%, 75% oxygen is not recommended as the starting concentration for neonatal resuscitation in term babies.

 

Educational Objective:


During neonatal resuscitation of a term baby, resuscitation should start with 21% oxygen, equivalent to room air, to minimize the risk of oxygen toxicity.

questions.text: What is the amount of milk given to term baby in first 24 hours after delivery? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 60ml/kg


The recommended amount of milk (or fluid) to be given to a term newborn in the first 24 hours after birth is 60 ml per kg of body weight. This guideline ensures that the newborn receives an adequate amount of fluid to meet its nutritional and hydration needs during the initial adaptation period after birth.

 

Educational Objective:


The appropriate amount of milk or fluid to be given to a term baby in the first 24 hours after delivery is 60 ml per kg of body weight.

questions.text: A 31-year-old lady with diabetes mellitus delivers a term neonate. Which of the following problems may be associated with the baby born to this lady? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypoglycemia

 

In infants born to mothers with diabetes mellitus, the most common complication observed is hypoglycemia. This occurs due to the infant's pancreas producing high levels of insulin in response to maternal hyperglycemia. After birth, the supply of glucose from the mother is cut off, but the infant's high insulin levels persist, leading to hypoglycemia.

 

Infants born to diabetic mothers may present with several complications, including:

 

  • Macrosomia (large for gestational age): Increased glucose in the maternal blood crosses the placenta, causing the fetus to produce more insulin, which leads to increased growth and fat deposition.
  • Hypoglycemia: Due to increased insulin production.
  • Respiratory distress syndrome: Maternal diabetes can delay fetal lung maturity.
  • Neural tube defects: Increased risk due to poorly controlled maternal diabetes.
  • Hypocalcemia: Low calcium levels in the neonate, often due to maternal magnesium deficiency.
  • Cardiomegaly and heart failure: Due to high insulin levels affecting cardiac tissue.
  • Congenital heart defects: Ventricular or atrial septal defects, and transposition of the great vessels are more common in infants of diabetic mothers.
  • Lumbosacral agenesis: A rare congenital disorder affecting the lower spine.
  • Renal anomalies: Hydronephrosis, renal agenesis, and dysplasia.
  • Gastrointestinal atresia: Duodenal or anorectal atresia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperglycemia: This is more likely to be seen in the mother rather than the infant. The infant typically experiences hypoglycemia due to high insulin levels.

 

Option B. Tetralogy of Fallot: This congenital heart defect is more commonly associated with genetic syndromes such as Down syndrome rather than maternal diabetes. Infants of diabetic mothers are more likely to have septal defects or transposition of the great vessels.

 

Option C. Hypercalcemia: Infants of diabetic mothers are more prone to hypocalcemia rather than hypercalcemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infants born to diabetic mothers are at increased risk of hypoglycemia due to high insulin levels.

questions.text: What is the recommended target preductal oxygen saturation (SpO₂) for neonates at 5 minutes after birth according to the Neonatal Resuscitation Program (NRP) 2010 guidelines? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. 80-85%

 

Explanation: 

 

According to the Neonatal Resuscitation Program (NRP) guidelines, the target preductal oxygen saturation (SpO₂) in neonates at 5 minutes after birth is 80-85%. This is part of the gradual progression of normal oxygen saturation values in the first 10 minutes after birth. The preductal SpO₂ is measured in the right upper limb (right hand).

 

The normal SpO₂ progression after birth is:

 

  • At 1 minute: 60-65%
  • At 2 minutes: 65-70%
  • At 3 minutes: 70-75%
  • At 4 minutes: 75-80%
  • At 5 minutes: 80-85%
  • At 10 minutes: 85-95%

 

To remember-

 

  • Start from 60
  • THEN ADD 5 for every minute till 5 minutes, only for the last 10 minutes - add 10
  • These targets acknowledge the normal physiological transition from fetal to neonatal circulation, where saturation gradually increases as the lungs expand and the pulmonary vascular resistance decreases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 70-75% - This is the target SpO₂ at 3 minutes after birth, not at 5 minutes.

 

Option B. 75-80% - This is the target SpO₂ at 4 minutes after birth, not at 5 minutes.

 

Option D. 85-95% - This is the target SpO₂ at 10 minutes after birth, not at 5 minutes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The normal physiologic transition after birth involves a gradual increase in oxygen saturation, with a target SpO₂ of 80-85% at 5 minutes of life. These targeted ranges guide oxygen therapy during neonatal resuscitation to avoid both hypoxemia and hyperoxemia.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gilbert syndrome

 

Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia refers to an elevated level of bilirubin in the blood that has not been processed by the liver into its conjugated form. Gilbert syndrome is a common genetic disorder that causes mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. This condition results from reduced activity of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, which is responsible for the conjugation of bilirubin in the liver.

 

Other Options:

 

Causes of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia: (Mnemonic: DR BHATIA)

 

Option A. Dubin-Johnson syndrome: This condition causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is a rare genetic disorder characterized by a defect in the liver's ability to secrete conjugated bilirubin into the bile ducts, leading to its buildup in the liver.

 

Option B. Rotor syndrome: Similar to Dubin-Johnson syndrome, Rotor syndrome also leads to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is a benign condition that results from a defect in the hepatic storage and excretion of conjugated bilirubin.

 

Option C. Biliary atresia: This condition also results in conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is a serious liver disease in infants where the bile ducts become inflamed and blocked, preventing bile from draining from the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gilbert syndrome is a common cause of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to reduced activity of the enzyme responsible for bilirubin conjugation.

choices.text: 50 breaths per minute or more

questions.text: Which of the following does NOT suggest a possible severe bacterial infection in a young infant according to the IMNCI criteria? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Axillary temperature of 37.5°C or above 

 

Explanation: 

 

The IMNCI (Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness) protocol uses specific clinical criteria to identify young infants with potential severe bacterial infections requiring urgent treatment. An axillary temperature of 37.5°C represents a normal body temperature and falls below the fever threshold of ≥38.0°C, which would indicate infection. A temperature between 36.5°C and 37.5°C is considered normal and would not trigger the "fever" classification in the IMNCI assessment.

 

The WHO IMNCI classification system specifically designates fever as temperature ≥38°C when assessing for possible severe bacterial infection. Without other clinical signs, a temperature of 37.5°C alone would be classified as "no fever" and would not meet criteria for antibiotic therapy or referral.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 50 breaths per minute or more - This is a danger sign in IMNCI assessment. The age-specific respiratory rate cutoffs (≥60/min for <2 months; ≥50/min for 2-12 months) define fast breathing, which is classified as pneumonia requiring antibiotic therapy or severe pneumonia if accompanied by chest indrawing.

 

Option B. 10 or more skin pustules - This IS considered a sign of possible severe bacterial infection. The IMNCI guidelines classify multiple skin pustules or a large skin infection as requiring systemic antibiotics due to risk of invasive bacterial disease.

 

Option D. Temperature less than 35.5°C - This IS a critical danger sign. Hypothermia in young infants strongly suggests sepsis and represents impaired thermoregulation. IMNCI classifies temperature <35.5°C as a danger sign requiring immediate referral after pre-referral antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In IMNCI assessment, normal temperature (36.5-37.5°C) does not trigger concern for severe bacterial infection, while fast breathing (age-specific rates), multiple skin infections, and hypothermia (<35.5°C) all represent important clinical signs requiring prompt antibiotic therapy and possible referral.

questions.text: After how many seconds of chest compressions and bag and mask ventilation, should we start the adrenaline? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 60 seconds

 

Adrenaline is administered during neonatal resuscitation when the heart rate remains below 60 beats per minute after 60 seconds of effective bag and mask ventilation, or if the heart rate remains below 60 despite adequate bag and mask ventilation for 30 seconds. The prompt administration of adrenaline is crucial for improving perfusion and achieving successful resuscitation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adrenaline should be administered when the heart rate is less than 60 beats per minute after 60 seconds of bag and mask ventilation.

questions.text: A newborn baby with feeble lower limb pulses and bounding upper limb pulses? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) COA (Coarctation of the Aorta)

 

In coarctation of the aorta (COA), there is a narrowing of the aorta, which is the main artery that carries blood from the heart to the rest of the body. This narrowing obstructs blood flow to the lower part of the body. As a result, there is reduced blood flow to the lower limbs, causing feeble pulses in the lower limbs. Meanwhile, the upper body and limbs experience higher blood pressure and bounding pulses due to the increased pressure load.

 

An X-ray of a patient with coarctation of the aorta may show the "figure of 3" sign, indicative of the abnormal aortic shape due to the narrowing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TGA (Transposition of the Great Arteries): In TGA, the major arteries are reversed, causing severe cyanosis. The X-ray shows an "egg on side" appearance, but this condition does not cause differential limb pulses.

 

Option C. TOF (Tetralogy of Fallot): This condition involves four heart defects that cause cyanosis and a "boot-shaped" heart on X-ray, not differential limb pulses.

 

Option D. Ebstein anomaly: This is a congenital heart defect affecting the tricuspid valve and the right side of the heart, leading to a "box-shaped" heart on X-ray, but it does not cause differential pulses between the upper and lower limbs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coarctation of the aorta (COA) is characterized by feeble lower limb pulses and bounding upper limb pulses due to aortic narrowing.

choices.text: Increase in partial pressure of oxygen (pa02)

questions.text: Which of the following is the main factor for the ductal closure postnatally? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increase in partial pressure of oxygen (pa02)

 

The increase in partial pressure of oxygen (paO2) is the main factor controlling the closure of the ductus arteriosus postnatally. Oxygen acts as a potent smooth muscle constrictor. When a newborn begins to breathe and cries, oxygen enters the lungs during inspiration, leading to an increase in paO2. This increased oxygen tension causes the smooth muscle in the ductus arteriosus to constrict, leading to its closure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase in systemic vascular resistance: While systemic vascular resistance does increase after birth due to the cessation of placental circulation, it is not the primary factor responsible for ductal closure.

 

Option C. Increase in circulating prostaglandin levels: Prostaglandins, particularly PGE2, help keep the ductus arteriosus open. After birth, the levels of circulating prostaglandins decrease, contributing to ductal closure, but an increase in prostaglandins would not cause closure.

 

Option D. Decrease in pulmonary venous resistance: Pulmonary vascular resistance decreases after birth as the lungs expand and fill with air, allowing blood to flow more easily through the pulmonary circulation. However, this is not the direct cause of ductal closure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The increase in partial pressure of oxygen (paO2) postnatally is the most important factor for the closure of the ductus arteriosus.

questions.text: A 8-year-old boy weighing 30 Kgs has been posted for surgical resection of a tumor. What is the daily maintenance fluid required for this child while he's NPO? (FMGE DEC 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1700 mL

 

As per history given the child weight is 30 kg needs 1700 cc of maintenance fluid each day.

 

For this calculation daily maintenance fluid, the following table is considered.

 

 

Calculation:

 

As per the question, the weight of the child is given as 30 Kgs.

 

So, the formula for >20 Kg is used.

 

1500 mL + (20 mL × weight more than 20 Kgs)

 

Since the child weight is 30 Kgs, he/she is 10 Kgs more.

 

Therefore, fluid required is

 

= 1500 mL + (20 mL × 10)

 

= 1500 mL + 200 mL

 

= 1700 mL/1700cc

 

Educational Objective:


To calculate daily maintenance fluid for children, use the formula based on their weight, adjusting for ranges over 10 and 20 kg.

questions.text: Tetralogy of Fallot is most commonly associated with which of the following: (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Downs syndrome

 

Downs syndrome is most commonly associated with Tetralogy of Fallot.

 

Tetralogy of Fallot

 

  • Ventricular septal defect
  • Subpulmonary stenosis
  • Overriding aorta
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)

 

 

Clinical features

 

  • Asymptomatic usually, rarely have severe cyanosis at birth, worsens as they get older
  • Loud, harsh murmur at upper sternal edge day 1
  • Do not usually develop heart failure

 

ECG

 

  • Normal at birth
  • RVH when older

 

Chest X-ray

 

  • Usually, normal
  • If older have upturned apex (boot shaped) + reduced vascular markings

 

 

Management

 

  • 10% require BT shunt in newborn if severely cyanosed
  • Most have elective repair at 6–9 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Klinefelter’s syndrome: Klinefelter’s syndrome is characterized by a male patient with tall stature, gynecomastia, and micropenis. It is not typically associated with Tetralogy of Fallot.

 

Option B. Edwards syndrome: Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18) is associated with physical abnormalities like rocker bottom feet and is not commonly associated with Tetralogy of Fallot.

 

Option D. Turner’s syndrome: Turner syndrome (45, X) is commonly associated with congenital heart defects such as bicuspid aortic valve and coarctation of the aorta, but not typically with Tetralogy of Fallot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetralogy of Fallot is a congenital heart defect that is most commonly associated with Down syndrome (trisomy 21).

choices.text: There is hypertrophy of ductus arteriosus.
Coarctation distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery
Supply is from posterior to anterior thoracic artery.
Collaterals develop to supply upper limb.

questions.text: A child presents with cold feet and a history of wearing socks even in the summers. On examination, lower limb pulses are diminished as compared to the radial pulse. Prominent radio femoral delay is present. What is the underlying condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coarctation distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery

 

The clinical presentation of cold feet, wearing socks even in summer, diminished lower limb pulses compared to radial pulses, and prominent radiofemoral delay is characteristic of coarctation of the aorta. This congenital condition is characterized by a narrowing (coarctation) of the aorta, typically just distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery at the ductus arteriosus.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Coarctation of the Aorta: This condition results in the obstruction of blood flow, leading to higher blood pressure in the upper limbs and lower blood pressure in the lower limbs. The radiofemoral delay is a classic sign.
  • Location of Coarctation:
    • Postductal Coarctation (Adult Type): The constriction occurs distal to the ductus arteriosus. This type is more common and leads to the development of collateral circulation to bypass the obstruction.
    • Predductal Coarctation (Infantile Type): The constriction occurs proximal to the ductus arteriosus, leading to different clinical features and often presenting in infancy.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Cold feet and preference for wearing socks may be due to poor perfusion in the lower extremities.
    • Diminished lower limb pulses and radiofemoral delay are hallmark signs.
    • Hypertension in the upper extremities due to the coarctation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypertrophy of ductus arteriosus: This condition does not cause radiofemoral delay or the constellation of symptoms seen in coarctation of the aorta.

 

Option C. Supply from posterior to anterior thoracic artery: This does not explain the clinical presentation, especially the radiofemoral delay.

 

Option D. Collaterals develop to supply upper limb: Collateral circulation is a compensatory mechanism that develops over time in coarctation of the aorta, primarily to supply blood to the lower extremities, not just the upper limbs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coarctation of the aorta typically presents with cold feet, diminished lower limb pulses, and radiofemoral delay due to a narrowing of the aorta distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery.

choices.text: IV fluids
Breast feeding
Orogastric tube feed
Paladai feeding

questions.text: What should be the best initial feeding method for a baby born at 33 weeks gestation, with no perinatal complications? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Paladai feeding

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

For preterm infants born between 32-34 weeks gestation, paladai feeding is recommended as the initial feeding method to ensure adequate nutrition and support the development of oral feeding skills.

questions.text: In PALS ABCDE all pairs are matched correctly except? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D for dehydration

 

All pairs are correctly matched except D for dehydration.

 

Here it Should be D for disability

 

In Pediatric Basic and Advanced Life Support (PALS) mnemonic “ABCDE” stands for as follow -

 

A - Airway

B - Breathing

C - Circulation

D - Disability

E - Exposure

 

First, life-threatening airway problems are assessed and treated; second, life-threatening breathing problems are assessed and treated; and so on.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In PALS, the "D" in the ABCDE mnemonic stands for Disability, which involves assessing the child’s neurological status.
